novel_text:
The mist, a restless spirit, clung to the dark waters of the fjord, its tendrils creeping up the steep, pine-stubbled slopes to where Bjørn Knutsen’s farm sat like a stubborn old man refusing to budge. The red paint on the barn was faded to the colour of dried blood, and the house, a sturdy construction of thick, dark timber, had watched over this valley for a hundred and fifty years. It had seen Knutsen men born and it had seen Knutsen men die, and it knew, with the certainty of ancient wood, that Bjørn was much like all the others. He was a man of the earth, of routine, of quiet satisfactions. The sun was a pale suggestion behind the eastern peaks, but Bjørn had been awake for an hour, his boots already caked in the rich, dark mud of the low pasture.

The air in the barn was a familiar cocktail: damp hay, the sweet-sour tang of silage, and the warm, animal musk of the twenty-three dairy cows who were, for all intents and purposes, his entire world. They were his colleagues, his confidantes, his silent, cud-chewing congregation. He moved between them, his hands, thick as cured hams and mapped with the calluses of a thousand chores, patting a flank here, scratching behind an ear there. Their gentle, lowing breaths were the rhythm section of his morning. He checked the feed. All was well. He topped up the water troughs, the gushing from the hose a sudden, loud intrusion into the morning’s quiet symphony. He reached Helga, his favourite, a grand dame of a Norwegian Red with eyes as deep and placid as a mountain tarn and a coat the colour of a rich sunset. She nudged his chest with her great, solid head, a demand for attention he was always happy to provide. He scratched the spot between her horns, and she let out a sigh of bovine contentment.

And then, as the first proper rays of sunlight finally broke over the ridge and speared through the dusty barn window, he began to sing.

It wasn't a conscious decision. It was as much a part of the routine as mucking out or checking the milking machines. His voice wasn't polished; it had none of the slick, auto-tuned perfection that bled from the radio in his daughter’s car. It was a voice that had been aged in woodsmoke and winter winds, a thing of texture and surprising grace. It was a baritone, deep and resonant, a sound that seemed to rise from the very soil he stood upon, yet it carried a tune with a startling, gentle precision. Today, it was Sinatra. “And now, the end is near, and so I face the final curtain...”

He sang it to Helga, whose ear twitched in time with the melody. He sang it to the motes of dust dancing in the sunbeams, to the swallows nesting in the rafters, to the ghosts of his father and his grandfather who had sung their own songs in this very barn. His voice filled the space, wrapping around the wooden beams, the notes finding a home among the scent of hay and honest work. It was a voice full of a life lived, of sorrows weathered and small joys fiercely held. It was, in its own rough-hewn way, magnificent.

“Papa, that was beautiful.”

Bjørn jumped, the final note of the song catching in his throat like a fishbone. He spun around, his heart thumping a sudden, panicked rhythm against his ribs. His daughter, Astrid, stood in the wide-open doorway, silhouetted against the bright morning, her phone held up like a small, black icon. She was sixteen, all long limbs and a knowing smile that made him feel both ancient and intensely proud.

“Astrid! By Odin’s beard, don’t sneak up on a man like that. You’ll give me a fright.” He wiped his hands on his trousers, a gesture of nervous habit. “And what are you doing with that... that thing?”

“Recording you,” she said, lowering the phone. Her smile widened, revealing a flash of braces. “I’ve told you for years. Your voice is a gift. It’s not just for the cows.”

Bjørn grunted, turning back to Helga and giving her another vigorous scratch. “The cows are a fine audience. They don’t judge. They don’t ask for an encore. And they certainly don’t record a man when he’s not looking.” He felt a flush of heat creep up his neck. It was one thing to sing in the privacy of his own barn, a private conversation between him, his herd, and his memories. It was another thing entirely to have it captured, trapped in one of those little electronic boxes.

“Well,” Astrid said, her voice taking on a tone of deliberate casualness that he had learned was always a prelude to trouble. “It’s too late. I sent it in.”

Bjørn stopped scratching. He turned slowly, his brow furrowed. “Sent it where?”

“To X-Factor,” she said, the words tumbling out in a rush. “X-Factor Norge. The auditions. I just... I cut together a few clips. The one of you singing ‘Hallelujah’ at the Christmas concert, and that bit of ‘Bridge Over Troubled Water’ you were humming while fixing the tractor, and this one. ‘My Way’. I thought it was appropriate.”

Bjørn stared at her. The sounds of the barn—the gentle chewing, the soft shifting of hooves on straw—seemed to fade into a dull roar in his ears. X-Factor. It was a joke. A television confection of flashing lights, manufactured tears, and impossibly white teeth. It was a world as alien to him as the surface of the moon. It was for teenagers with dyed hair and city folk with desperate, hungry eyes. It was not for a fifty-two-year-old farmer from a forgotten corner of Vestland.

“You did what?” His voice was dangerously quiet.

“I just thought… you deserve it, Papa. You love it so much. Why should it always be a secret?” Her bravado was beginning to crack, her eyes wide and pleading. “They probably won’t even watch it. It’s just… a lottery ticket. A bit of fun.”

He wanted to be angry. He wanted to tell her to delete it, to tell these television people it was a mistake, a child’s prank. But he couldn't. He looked at his daughter, at the fierce, hopeful belief shining in her face, and the anger wouldn't come. He just felt a deep, bone-weary tiredness, and something else, a tiny, fluttering thing in his chest he refused to name. He sighed, the sound like the wind leaking through an old window frame. “Astrid, my girl. Life is not a television show.”

“Maybe it could be,” she whispered. “Just a little bit.”

He shook his head and went back to his chores, the comfortable silence of his morning shattered. The rest of the day was filled with a low-level thrum of anxiety. Every time the tractor backfired, he thought it was a television van coming up the lane. He looked at his cows and felt a pang of guilt, as if he had already betrayed them. X-Factor. The absurdity of it was a bitter taste in his mouth.

Three weeks passed. The incident was not mentioned again. The snows began to melt in earnest on the high peaks, feeding the waterfalls that tumbled down the mountainsides in roaring white torrents. The rhythm of the farm reasserted itself, and Bjørn let the memory of Astrid’s confession fade, dismissing it as a flight of teenage fancy.

He was in the kitchen, nursing a cup of coffee so strong it could dissolve a spoon, staring out at the rain lashing against the windowpane, when the phone rang. It was the landline, a rare occurrence in an age of mobiles. Usually, it was just a wrong number or a salesperson trying to sell him a new roof. He let it ring five times before Astrid, doing her homework at the big wooden table, looked up at him.

“Aren’t you going to get it?”

With a grunt, he heaved himself up and picked up the receiver. “Knutsen.”

The voice on the other end was crisp, female, and utterly urban. It spoke a slick, Oslo-inflected Norwegian that sounded jarringly out of place in his rustic kitchen. “Good afternoon, am I speaking with Bjørn Knutsen?”

“You are.”

“Wonderful. My name is Sofia Dahl, I’m a producer with Titan Productions. We work on a little show called X-Factor Norge.”

Bjørn’s grip tightened on the phone. The little fluttering thing in his chest was back, and this time it felt less like a butterfly and more like a trapped bird. He glanced at Astrid. Her head was bent over her books, but he could see from the tension in her shoulders that she was listening to every word.

“We received an audition video,” the voice continued, oblivious to the silent drama unfolding in the farmhouse. “A collection of songs. Very... authentic. The panel was quite taken with it. Unanimously, in fact. We don't usually do this, but the raw quality of the voice… it’s precisely what we’re looking for this season. Something real.”

Bjørn said nothing. He didn’t know what to say. He was a man who spoke of cattle feed prices and the probability of rain. He did not speak of ‘raw quality’ or television panels.

“Mr. Knutsen? Are you still there?”

“I’m here,” he managed, his voice a dry croak.

“Excellent. We would like to formally invite you to the televised audition round in Oslo. We’d cover your travel and accommodation, of course. It would be next Thursday.”

Oslo. The word itself sounded like a foreign country. A place of noise and crowds and people who moved too fast. What would he do in Oslo? What would he do with his cows? Who would mend the fence on the north pasture that a winter storm had weakened? This was madness. A fantasy belonging to his daughter, not to him.

“I… I don’t think so,” he said, the words tasting of defeat and relief in equal measure. “It’s a mistake. I’m a farmer.”

“We know,” Sofia Dahl said, her voice softening slightly, becoming persuasive. “That’s the appeal, Bjørn. May I call you Bjørn? The Singing Farmer. The story is fantastic. The voice is even better. Just come for the one audition. No commitment. Sing one song for the judges. If it doesn’t work out, you go home with a fun story to tell. What do you have to lose?”

He looked at Astrid again. She had finally lifted her head, and her eyes were shining with unshed tears, her face a mask of desperate hope. She was looking at him as if he held the entire world in his hands. In that moment, he knew he was lost. He thought of his late wife, Ingrid, who had always told him he hid his light under a bushel. He thought of the long, dark winters and the endless cycle of chores. He thought of the little spark that came to life inside him when he sang, a spark he had so carefully dampened for so many years.

What did he have to lose? His quiet life. His dignity. His peace.

What did he have to gain? He had no idea.

“Alright,” he heard himself say, the word feeling alien in his own mouth. “Alright. I’ll come.”

The squeal of delight from Astrid was so loud he had to pull the phone away from his ear. On the other end, the producer’s professional calm returned instantly. “Fantastic, Bjørn. Absolutely fantastic. We’ll have a car pick you up on Wednesday morning. Welcome to the show.”

The line went dead. Bjørn stood holding the receiver, listening to the dial tone as if it might offer some explanation for what he had just done. He had just agreed to trade the familiar scent of hay and earth for the sterile chill of a television studio. He had agreed to stand on a stage, under blinding lights, and offer up the most private part of himself for public consumption and judgment. He hung up the phone and looked out the window. The rain had stopped, and a sliver of rainbow was arching over the fjord, its colours impossibly bright against the dark, brooding mountains. It looked beautiful and utterly unreal. A promise of something he couldn't quite grasp. He felt a tremor of fear, but beneath it, buried deep, was a flicker of something he hadn't felt in a very, very long time: pure, terrifying excitement.The days that followed were a strange, waking dream. Astrid floated through them on a cloud of giddy excitement, her phone buzzing constantly with messages from the production company, confirming details he didn't want to hear. She spoke of schedules and song choices and what he should wear, her voice a constant, cheerful hum against the backdrop of his mounting dread. He, in turn, retreated deeper into the familiar rituals of the farm. He mucked out the barn with a furious energy, repaired a sagging gate he’d been meaning to fix for months, and spent long, silent hours in the high pastures, just watching the clouds drift over the peaks, trying to memorise the feeling of the wind on his face and the solid ground beneath his feet. He felt like a man preparing for his own execution.

His conversation with their neighbour, Lars, was excruciating. Lars was a stooped, wiry man with a face like a weathered apple, and he’d known Bjørn his entire life. To ask him to look after the herd for a few days felt like a confession of madness. “Going to the city?” Lars had asked, his pale blue eyes squinting in suspicion. “A family matter,” Bjørn had mumbled, unable to meet his gaze. The lie felt clumsy and heavy in his mouth. Lars, to his credit, just nodded. In their valley, people knew not to pry, but Bjørn could feel the unspoken questions hanging in the air between them. He felt like a traitor, abandoning his post for a fool’s errand.

The night before they were to leave, Astrid laid out his clothes on his bed. It was the dark grey suit he had worn to his father’s funeral and then, a decade later, to Ingrid’s. It smelled faintly of mothballs and sorrow. He looked at it, then at the plaid flannel shirt and worn woollen jumper laid beside it. “I am not wearing a suit, Astrid. I will look like a stuffed bear.” His daughter crossed her arms, adopting a look of stern patience she had likely learned from her mother. “Papa, you are not mending a fence. You are going on television. You need to look… respectable.” He ended up compromising, agreeing to pack the suit but insisting on travelling in his usual attire, much to her theatrical sighing. He felt like a child being dressed for a party he had no wish to attend.

The car arrived precisely at eight in the morning. It was a black, gleaming Mercedes, so clean it seemed to repel the farm’s inherent coating of mud and honesty. It crunched to a halt on the gravel, its engine a low, expensive purr that sounded obscene next to the gentle lowing of the cows. The driver was a young man in a dark suit who looked as though he had never seen a real-life chicken. He took Bjørn’s single, battered suitcase and placed it in the boot with a reverence it did not deserve. Before getting in, Bjørn walked back to the barn one last time. Helga was in her usual stall, her big head hanging over the gate. He rested his forehead against hers, the warmth and familiar, earthy smell of her a comfort that almost broke him. “You be good now, old girl,” he whispered, his voice thick. “I’ll be back before you know it.” She blinked her placid, dark eyes, as if to say she knew better than to believe such promises.

The journey was a slow, agonizing severance. For the first few hours, the road clung to the side of the fjord, a familiar ribbon of asphalt twisting through a landscape he knew as well as his own hand. He watched his valley, his mountains, his water, recede in the rear-view mirror until they were just a watercolour smudge in the distance. Astrid chattered excitedly beside him, pointing out landmarks and reading facts about the X-Factor judges from her phone. He just nodded, his throat too tight for words, feeling as though an invisible tether connecting him to his home was being stretched thinner and thinner with every kilometre, threatening to snap.

As they descended from the mountains and the land flattened into rolling fields and then sprawling suburbs, the world outside the window grew more cluttered and unfamiliar. The quiet solitude of his life was replaced by the rush of traffic, the blur of signs, the anonymous faces of a thousand strangers. By the time they reached the outskirts of Oslo, the low thrum of anxiety in his chest had grown into a pounding drum. The city rose up around them, a forest of concrete and glass that blocked out the sky. It was a place of sharp angles and hard surfaces, so different from the soft, ancient curves of his mountains. The driver navigated the dense traffic with an easy confidence that Bjørn found both impressive and deeply unsettling. He felt like a stone being carried along by a flood, powerless to do anything but be swept away. When the car finally pulled up outside a sleek, modern hotel that looked more like an art gallery than a place to sleep, Bjørn felt a profound and terrifying sense of dislocation. He was no longer on his own land. He was a stranger in a strange world, and the only thing he had to his name was a song he wasn’t even sure he could remember how to sing.The hotel lobby was a cathedral of quiet wealth and impersonality. Polished marble floors reflected the cold, recessed lighting, and the air smelled of some faint, synthetic floral scent that scraped at the back of Bjørn’s throat. A woman with a severe haircut and a fixed, polite smile checked them in, her fingers flying over a keyboard with a series of clicks that sounded like tiny, angry insects. Astrid, by his side, was wide-eyed, drinking it all in, but Bjørn felt a crushing sense of claustrophobia. The walls, decorated with abstract art that looked to him like expensive, colourful mistakes, seemed to be closing in. Their room on the ninth floor was even worse. It was a sterile white box, dominated by a bed so vast and pristine he was afraid to sit on it. A television screen the size of a small sheep hung on the wall opposite, dark and silent like a dead eye. He went to the window, expecting a view, but all he saw was the flank of another glass-and-steel building, its windows reflecting his own tired, bewildered face back at him.

That evening, Astrid’s pleas to explore the city, to see the Royal Palace or walk along the harbour, fell on deaf ears. The thought of navigating the crowded streets filled him with a weariness that went bone-deep. They ordered food to the room, a decision that resulted in the arrival of a trolley laden with small, elaborately arranged dishes. He pushed a piece of pink fish around his plate with a fork that felt flimsy and ridiculous in his hand. It tasted of nothing, a ghost of a meal. He tried to call Lars, a desperate need for a connection to his real life gnawing at him, but the old farmer didn't answer. Bjørn stared at the phone, imagining his herd settling down for the night, the familiar sounds and smells of the barn, and the feeling of being untethered became a physical ache in his chest. Later, as Astrid slept, her breathing a soft, steady rhythm in the oppressive silence, he lay awake for hours, a prisoner in the crisp, cold sheets, listening to the alien hum of the city and feeling a thousand kilometres from home.

He was awake long before the first hint of grey dawn touched the Oslo sky, his internal clock set to a sunrise he couldn't see and chores he couldn't perform. The feeling of uselessness was profound. He paced the small room like a caged animal until Astrid stirred, her excitement from the day before now tinged with a nervous energy that mirrored his own. The battle of the suit resumed. He held up the heavy, dark wool, the fabric stiff with memory and disuse. “I cannot sing in this,” he stated, his voice a low rumble. “It is a costume for a dead man.” Astrid, already dressed in a smart blouse that made her look older than her sixteen years, held her ground. “Papa, it’s about respect. For the judges, for the audience.” In the end, he relented, pulling on the suit trousers and buttoning the crisp shirt with his thick, clumsy fingers. He felt trussed up and absurd, a caricature of a serious man. As he struggled with the knot of his tie, he caught his reflection in the mirror. A farmer in a suit. He looked like his own lawyer, or his own undertaker.

The same black car whisked them away through the morning rush hour. If the city had been overwhelming yesterday, today it was a monstrous, roaring beast. The sheer volume of people, all moving with such purpose, made him feel slow and obsolete. He kept his eyes fixed on the window but saw nothing, his mind filled with images of the fjord, the way the light hit the water in the late afternoon, the sound of the wind in the high pines. Without thinking, his hand went into his pocket and closed around a small, smooth, grey stone he’d picked up from the shore of the fjord weeks ago. He had no memory of putting it there, but its familiar weight in his palm was the only real thing in a world that had become flimsy and unreal. The pressure of it against his skin was an anchor, a tiny piece of home he had brought with him into the belly of the whale.

The backstage area of the television studio was not a place of glamour, but of controlled chaos. It was a dark, cavernous space, a tangle of thick black cables snaking across the floor, towering scaffolds of lights, and busy, headset-wearing people scurrying about like ants whose hill had been kicked. A dozen other hopefuls were scattered around the starkly lit waiting area. They were so young. A girl with hair the colour of a tropical bird practiced piercing vocal runs that made Bjørn’s teeth ache. A trio of boys in matching, too-tight jackets preened for a selfie, their faces masks of practiced confidence. They glanced at him, this grey-haired, broad-shouldered man in his ill-fitting funeral suit, their eyes holding a mixture of pity and bemused curiosity. The label he’d overheard a crew member whisper into a microphone—‘The Singing Farmer’—seemed to hang in the air around him. It wasn't a description; it was a brand, a story they had written for him before he had even sung a note.

A woman with sharp blonde hair, a sharper suit, and a tablet computer clutched like a shield detached herself from a hurried conversation and glided towards him. Her smile was bright, white, and completely devoid of warmth. “Bjørn! Sofia Dahl.” It was the voice from the phone. “So glad you made it. You look wonderful.” He nodded, feeling the lie of her compliment settle uncomfortably on his shoulders. “The panel is very intrigued,” she continued, her eyes scanning his face as if checking for any blemishes in her product. “The story, the authenticity… it’s gold. Just go out there, be yourself, sing from the heart. They’re going to love you.” Her words were meant to be encouraging, but they only confirmed his deepest fear. He wasn’t a man here; he was a story. A marketable commodity. He was the farmer, the novelty act, and his song was just part of the package.

He was guided to a small, curtained-off area at the side of the stage. Through a gap, he could see the intimidating sweep of the auditorium, a vast darkness dotted with the tiny lights of a thousand mobile phones. He could hear the muffled roar of the crowd and the deep, amplified voice of the host warming them up. His heart, which had been pounding a steady, nervous rhythm, began to hammer against his ribs like a trapped thing. His mouth was as dry as dust. He thought of Helga, of the feel of her coarse coat under his hand. He thought of the smell of the earth after rain. He thought of Ingrid, and the quiet way she would hum along when he sang in the kitchen. What was he doing here? This world of noise and light and manufactured emotion had no place for him. Just as the thought of turning and walking away began to solidify into a real plan, Astrid appeared at his side. Her own face was pale now, the giddy excitement replaced by a raw, naked fear that mirrored his own. She didn't speak. She just took his huge, callused hand in her two small ones and squeezed. “Sing for Mama,” she whispered, her voice trembling. “She always loved to hear you sing.”

The host’s voice boomed from the stage, suddenly clear and deafeningly loud. “He’s a fifty-two-year-old dairy farmer from a tiny village in Vestland who has never sung for anyone but his twenty-three cows! Please give a huge X-Factor welcome to Bjørn Knutsen!” A wave of applause and cheering, impossibly loud, washed over him. A young man with a headset appeared in the gap of the curtain, his face impassive. He pointed towards the stage. “You’re on, Bjørn. Go.” The world seemed to shrink to the narrow path ahead of him: a few steps of darkness, and then a blinding wall of white light. He looked at the stage, at the judgment that awaited him, and then back at his daughter’s tear-streaked, hopeful face. His feet felt like they were nailed to the floor. For a heartbeat that stretched into an eternity, he did nothing, trapped between the life he knew and the terrifying, brilliant unknown.The pressure of his daughter’s small hands on his own was a physical anchor in the swirling chaos of sound and fear. Her words, a tremulous whisper about his late wife, cut through the noise, finding a place deep inside him that had nothing to do with television or judges or a roaring crowd. He wasn't doing this for them. He wasn't a product to be sold. He was a husband singing a song his wife had loved. He was a father granting a daughter’s fierce, improbable wish. The fjord stone was a cold, hard knot of reality in his palm. He squeezed it once, a final, silent pact with the man he had been his entire life, and then he took a step forward, out of the shadows and into the blinding, unforgiving light.

The heat hit him first, a dry, intense warmth radiating from a constellation of unseen lamps above. The world beyond the edge of the stage vanished into a vast, swallowing darkness, but the noise that came from it was a physical force, a wave of cheering and applause that washed over him and threatened to sweep him from his feet. He walked towards the centre of the stage, his boots, meticulously cleaned by Astrid but still carrying the memory of mud, feeling clumsy and loud on the polished black floor. Far in front of him, behind a long, glowing desk, sat four figures. They were rendered unreal by the distance and the powerful lights, looking less like people and more like a tribunal of distant gods waiting to pass judgment. He stopped at the designated spot, a simple metal microphone stand his only shield, and blinked against the glare, feeling utterly exposed, a large, solitary tree transplanted to a sterile desert.

“Welcome, Bjørn,” said a voice, amplified and impossibly smooth. It belonged to a man with sharp, fashionable glasses and a kind smile that didn't quite reach his eyes. “We’ve heard a lot about you. The farmer from Vestland. Is it true you normally only sing to your cows?” A ripple of gentle laughter went through the unseen audience. Bjørn’s throat was tight. He swallowed, the sound loud in his own ears, and leaned towards the microphone. “Yes,” he said, his voice coming out as a rough, quiet rasp. “They are a good audience.” Another judge, a famous female pop star with glittering eyeshadow and a bored expression, leaned forward. “And what do the cows think? Are you any good?” The question was laced with a casual, almost cruel amusement. Bjørn looked past her, into the darkness where thousands of strangers sat waiting to be entertained. He thought of Helga’s soft, lowing sigh of contentment. “They seem to enjoy it,” he said, the simple honesty of his answer creating a small pocket of silence.

The first judge smiled again. “Well, we are not cows, Bjørn. But we are all ears. What are you going to sing for us today?” This was the moment. He had planned, with Astrid’s insistent coaching, to sing the Simon & Garfunkel song. It was safe, it was known. But standing there, in the funeral suit, feeling like an imposter, the English words felt foreign and false in his mouth. He couldn’t do it. He couldn’t offer them a borrowed song. He had to give them something that was his, something from the soil he stood upon even when he was a thousand kilometres away. He took a deep breath, the stale, air-conditioned air a poor substitute for the pine-scented breeze of his valley. “It is an old song,” he said, his voice a little stronger now. “A stev. From my home.” He saw a flicker of confusion on the judges’ faces. This wasn't on their list. This wasn't part of the pop-culture pantheon they inhabited. For the first time, a sliver of control returned to him. This song, they did not own.

He didn't wait for their permission. He closed his eyes, shutting out the lights, the cameras, the four sets of judging eyes. He shut out the entire artifice of the moment and, in the sudden, welcome darkness of his own mind, he went home. He saw the mist on the fjord, felt the solid weight of the barn’s ancient timber beams around him, and smelled the sweet, damp scent of hay. He pictured his father’s hands, callused and strong like his own, and his grandfather’s stoic silence. He thought of Ingrid, her face young and bright, laughing in the summer sun. And then, into the charged silence of the vast auditorium, he let the first note rise. It wasn't loud. It was a sound as quiet and deep as the dark water of the fjord, a single, mournful tone that seemed to carry the weight of a hundred winters.

The song was simple, a lament of a man leaving his valley, promising the mountains he will return. It had no complex melody, no soaring chorus. It was raw and unadorned, a thing of texture and deep, resonant sorrow. His baritone voice, freed from the prison of his anxiety, filled the space not with power, but with presence. Each note was clear, precise, and heavy with an emotion that was utterly, devastatingly real. He wasn't performing; he was testifying. He sang of the unforgiving stone and the brief, brilliant green of summer, of the darkness of the polar night and the fierce joy of the returning sun. The audience, which had been rustling with anticipation, fell into a profound, collective hush. The odd cough or shuffle died away. The entire cavernous room seemed to be holding its breath, listening not to a contestant on a talent show, but to the voice of the land itself. The final note hung in the air, a perfect, fading echo, and in the silence that followed, Bjørn opened his eyes.

He was momentarily disoriented, the sudden return of the blinding lights a physical shock. He felt the sweat on his brow, the dampness of the shirt under his suit. For a long moment, there was no sound at all. The silence was more terrifying than the noise had been. He had failed. He had given them something they didn't understand, something too old and too sad for their glittering world. He looked down at the floor, waiting for the polite dismissal. And then, it started. Not an explosion of cheering, but a single pair of hands clapping, then a few more, and then, in a rising, swelling wave, the entire auditorium erupted. It was a sound unlike the welcome applause; it was a roar of genuine, thunderous acclaim, deep and sustained. He looked up at the judges’ table. The bored pop star was wiping a tear from the corner of her eye. The sharp-faced man who had asked about the cows was staring at him, his mouth slightly agape. The kind-eyed judge had simply removed his glasses and was shaking his head slowly, in disbelief.

“Bjørn,” the kind judge finally said, his voice thick with emotion. “In all my years of doing this show, I have been entertained, I have been impressed… but I don’t know if I have ever been so truly moved. That was… that was not a performance. That was a piece of our soul. Where did that come from?” Bjørn clutched the fjord stone in his pocket. “It comes from home,” he said simply. The fourth judge, a brash music producer known for his brutal honesty, spoke for the first time. “I don’t know what that song was, and I don’t care. I don’t sell records in that language. But what I just heard… that’s a voice that has lived. That’s a voice people will believe. It’s a hundred times more real than anything else we’ll hear tonight. For me, it’s a yes.” The pop star nodded, still dabbing at her eye. “It is a yes from me.” The sharp-faced man simply said, “Of course it’s a yes.” The kind judge put his glasses back on, a broad, genuine smile finally spreading across his face. “Bjørn Knutsen, you are not just a singer for your cows anymore. You have four yeses. You’re going through.”

The roar from the crowd was deafening now. Bjørn just stood there, nodding numbly as the host came out to shake his hand and guide him off the stage. The words, the praise, the noise—it all washed over him without truly penetrating. He walked back into the darkness of the wings, his legs unsteady. Astrid was there, her face a mess of joyful tears, and she threw herself into his arms, sobbing with relief and pride. “You did it, Papa! You did it! It was magnificent!” He held her, patting her back with a hand that felt disconnected from his body. He had done it. He had faced the lights and the judgment and he had won. But as he stood there, the thunderous applause still echoing in his ears, he felt no triumph. He only felt a profound and hollow ache, the sorrowful certainty that the quiet, private world he had sung about was a world he could never fully return to.The whirlwind did not stop at the edge of the stage. As Bjørn held his weeping daughter, the controlled chaos of the backstage area enveloped them. Sofia Dahl was the first to reach him, her sharp smile now seeming genuine, predatory. Her eyes gleamed with the thrill of a successful gamble. “Gold, Bjørn! Pure gold!” she exclaimed, her voice a pitch higher than before. “The authenticity! The tears! The panel is ecstatic, the online buzz is already starting. We need to get a quick interview with the digital team, just a few words about how you’re feeling. Your story is everything we hoped for.” She was already steering him towards a brightly lit corner where a young man with a microphone was waiting, but Bjørn dug his heels in, a stubborn mule refusing to be led. The hand not holding Astrid went up, a simple, firm gesture of refusal. He felt a visceral revulsion at the idea of dissecting the moment, of packaging his raw emotion for mass consumption.

“No,” he said, the word a stone dropped into her river of effusive praise. “No interview.” He looked past her, his gaze sweeping over the scurrying crew members and the other wide-eyed contestants. He saw their faces, a mixture of awe and envy, and felt no kinship with them. He was not one of them. He was a man who had strayed impossibly far from his pasture, and every instinct screamed for him to find his way back. Sofia’s smile tightened for a fraction of a second before her professional mask slipped back into place. “Of course, of course. Overwhelmed. I understand completely. We’ll save it for tomorrow. For now, get some rest. You’ve earned it.” She patted his arm with a proprietary air that made his skin crawl, before turning to issue a rapid-fire set of instructions into her headset. Bjørn pulled Astrid gently towards the exit, his only thought to escape the suffocating heat and the relentless hum of the machine he had just fed so perfectly.

The ride back to the hotel was cloaked in a heavy silence that the sleek purr of the Mercedes engine could not penetrate. Astrid, her tears dried but her face still flushed with excitement, kept stealing glances at him. She opened her mouth to speak several times, to replay the judges’ words, to talk about the messages already flooding her phone from friends who had been watching. But something in his rigid posture, in the way he stared unseeingly at the blur of city lights, kept her quiet. He had returned to the car a different man from the one who had left it. The fear was gone, replaced by a deep, hollow stillness, a quietude that was far more unsettling than his earlier anxiety. He was like one of his own fields after the harvest, emptied out, the vital part of him gathered and taken away, leaving behind only stubble and silence.

Back in the sterile white box of the hotel room, the first thing he did was strip off the suit jacket and wrench the tie from his neck as if it were a noose. He threw them onto a chair with a contempt that made Astrid flinch. He didn’t want to look at the clothes, a costume for a man he did not recognize. He went to the window and stood with his back to the room, his hands braced on the cool glass, looking down at the endless, glittering grid of Oslo. It was a vast and intricate web of light, beautiful in its own alien way, but it offered no comfort. Each light was a window, a life, a story he did not know and had no wish to learn. He felt the weight of all those unknown lives pressing in on him, and the solitude he had always cherished on his farm now felt like a desperate, unattainable dream. The victory on the stage had not made him feel bigger; it had made him feel smaller, a single, lost note in a symphony he couldn't comprehend.

“Papa?” Astrid’s voice was small, tentative. “Aren’t you happy? You were amazing. Everyone loved you. You did what Mama always said you should.” The mention of his wife was a key turning in a lock he had kept rusted shut. He turned from the window, and his face was a landscape of such profound weariness that it stole her breath. “Your mother wanted me to share a gift, Astrid,” he said, his voice low and gravelly. “She did not want me to sell it at market.” The metaphor hung in the air between them, stark and agricultural. “They don’t care about the song. They care about the story. The Singing Farmer. It’s a curiosity. A sad old man and his sad old songs. They will put me in a pot and show me off, and when the novelty fades, they will put me on the compost heap.” He shook his head, a gesture of deep, internal pain. “They did not hear the song, my girl. They only heard the story they wanted to tell.”

The shrill ringing of Astrid’s phone cut through the tension. She looked at the screen, her eyes widening. “It’s the farm,” she whispered, holding the phone out to him as if it were a hot coal. It was their landline, the number he had given Lars for emergencies, now routed through the incomprehensible magic of modern technology. He took the phone, his thumb hovering over the green icon. The thought of speaking to Lars, of trying to explain this madness to a man whose reality was bounded by the weather and the price of milk, filled him with a quiet dread. He pressed the button. “Knutsen,” he said, his voice flat. On the other end, he heard the familiar crackle of the old landline, a sound of home so potent it made his throat ache. “Bjørn? It’s Lars.” There was a pause. Bjørn could picture him perfectly, standing in his own rustic kitchen, the receiver pressed to his ear, his face etched with confusion. “The missus was watching that silly music show on the television. She said she saw a man who looked a lot like you.”Bjørn held the phone to his ear, the world of the hotel room—the sterile white walls, the vast, silent television, his daughter’s anxious face—fading into an irrelevant haze. The crackle on the line was the sound of reality reasserting itself, a lifeline thrown across a chasm of noise and illusion. Lars’s simple, bewildered words carried more weight than all the judges’ effusive praise. They were a message from a world where consequences were real, where a man’s presence mattered, where life and well-being were not abstract concepts but tangible facts measured in bales of hay and the contentment of a herd.

“Yes, Lars. It was me,” Bjørn said, his voice flat and devoid of the triumph Astrid so desperately wanted to hear. He sank down onto the edge of the pristine bed, the perfect white duvet compressing under his weight. “It’s a long story.”

“I’ll wager it is,” Lars replied, his tone shifting from bewilderment to the familiar, dry cadence of a fellow farmer. There was no judgment, only a shared understanding of the absurdity of it all. “Well, your business is your own. But I am calling about Helga. She’s not right. Hasn’t touched her feed since yesterday evening. She won’t come in from the low pasture. Just stands by the gate, looking down the road. I’ve seen a cow mourn before, Bjørn. She’s mourning you.”

The words struck Bjørn with the force of a physical blow. Not a sickness, not an injury, but a sorrow. A quiet, stubborn protest from the one creature whose opinion he valued above all others. He saw her in his mind’s eye, his grand dame, her coat the colour of a rich sunset, standing alone in the damp field, her great, solid head facing the empty road, waiting. The manufactured drama of the television studio, the flashing lights and roaring crowds, seemed pathetic and foolish in the face of that simple, powerful image. He had betrayed his congregation. He had broken the faith. The hollow ache in his chest sharpened into a specific, agonizing pang of guilt.

“I’m coming home, Lars,” he said, and the decision, once made, settled in his bones with the certainty of bedrock. “I’m coming home now.” He ended the call before Lars could reply and dropped the phone onto the bed. He stood up, a man suddenly possessed of a singular, undeniable purpose. The anxiety and dislocation that had plagued him for days were gone, burned away by the cold, clear fire of necessity. He knew what he had to do.

“Papa, what is it? What’s wrong?” Astrid asked, her own excitement draining away as she saw the change that had come over him.

“We’re leaving,” he said, pulling his battered suitcase from the wardrobe. He began to unbutton the shirt he wore, the fine cotton suddenly feeling like a straitjacket. “Pack your things. We are going home.”

Astrid stared at him, her face a mask of disbelief. “Home? But you can’t! You won! You’re through to the next round! Sofia said they’d call tomorrow about the bootcamp week. This is it, Papa! This is the chance!” Her voice rose, bordering on frantic. “You can’t just walk away!”

He stopped, his shirt half undone, and looked at his daughter. He saw the dream in her eyes, so bright and fierce, and for the first time, he found the words to explain the darkness she could not see. “My chance for what, Astrid? To sing sad songs in a suit while my life falls apart a thousand kilometres away? Helga is sick because I am not there. My work is not a story for television, it is my life. It is who I am. That man on the stage… that was just a ghost. I need to go back to where I am solid.” He pulled the shirt off and reached for his familiar, worn flannel, the soft, familiar fabric a comfort against his skin. “This is my home. You are my home. The farm is my home. There is nothing for me here.”

Tears welled in Astrid’s eyes, born of frustration and a dawning, painful understanding. She saw the finality in his expression, the absolute certainty of a man who had looked over the edge of a cliff and chosen to step back. The argument died on her lips. She nodded, a small, jerky movement, and turned to her own bag, her shoulders slumped in defeat. The silence in the room was thick with the weight of a dream breaking. While she packed, Bjørn took the suit jacket and trousers, folded them neatly, and laid them on the hotel armchair. He left them there, an offering to the man he had briefly been, a skin shed and abandoned. He did not look back.

He ignored the sleek black car and the production company’s careful schedule. With Astrid trailing silently behind him, he walked out of the hotel’s sterile lobby and into the chilly morning air of the city. He hailed a taxi, a battered vehicle that smelled of stale coffee and air freshener, and gave the driver the name of the central train station. The journey through the city was a blur, but this time, Bjørn felt a grim sense of resolve. He was no longer a piece of driftwood; he was a salmon fighting his way back upstream, driven by an instinct more powerful than fame or fortune. At the station, he bought two one-way tickets on the next train heading west, paying with cash, the crisp notes a final, tangible severing of ties.

The long train ride home was the slow, steady stitching back together of his soul. As the endless sprawl of suburbs gave way to forests, then to hills, and finally to the first glimpses of the towering, snow-dusted peaks of his own land, he felt the tension leaving his body, muscle by muscle. He watched the landscape he loved unfold outside the window, not with the ache of longing, but with the quiet joy of return. He saw a herd of sheep scattered across a steep, green slope and felt a pang of connection, not pity. He saw the cold, grey water of a fjord reflecting a sky the colour of slate and felt its beauty as a personal welcome. Astrid, who had been withdrawn and silent for the first few hours, eventually pulled out an earbud and watched him. She saw the hard lines around his mouth soften, the haunted look in his eyes replaced by a quiet focus. She saw him returning to himself, and the last remnants of her anger dissolved into a quiet, reluctant understanding.

When they finally stepped off the train at the small local station, the air that greeted them was sharp, clean, and smelled of wet earth and pine. It was the scent of his own life. Lars was waiting for them, leaning against his old, mud-spattered pickup truck, his weathered face impassive. There were no recriminations in his eyes, only a quiet acknowledgement. The drive up the winding road to the farm was a final ascent into grace. When the red barn and the dark timber of the house came into view, sitting stubbornly on the slope overlooking the fjord, Bjørn felt a wave of relief so profound it almost brought him to his knees. He was home.

Before he even took his suitcase from the truck, he walked straight to the low pasture. And there she was. Helga stood by the gate, exactly as Lars had described, a statue of patient sorrow. She lifted her great head as he approached, and a low, guttural sound rumbled in her deep chest. Bjørn unlatched the gate and walked to her side, his hand landing on the warm, solid expanse of her flank. He leaned his forehead against hers, closing his eyes. “I’m here now, old girl,” he whispered, his voice thick. “I’m home.” She nudged him, a firm, insistent pressure against his chest, and let out a long, shuddering sigh of pure, bovine contentment. Lars watched from a distance, then turned and walked back to his truck with a quiet nod. Some things required no further explanation.

Later, as the evening mist began its restless dance on the dark waters below, Bjørn Knutsen was back in his barn. The air was a familiar cocktail, a comforting balm to his frayed senses. He moved between his silent, cud-chewing congregation, his hands reacquainting themselves with the familiar textures of his life. Astrid appeared in the doorway, not with a phone, but with two steaming mugs of coffee. She handed one to him, and they stood in silence for a long time, watching the cows settle for the night. And then, quietly, more to himself than to anyone else, Bjørn began to sing. It was not Sinatra, nor was it the ancient, mournful stev. It was a simple folk tune, a lullaby his wife used to hum. His voice, rich and resonant, filled the barn, not with sorrow or ambition, but with the simple, profound grace of a man who had found his way back to the only stage that ever mattered.The days that followed his return were a balm. The rhythm of the farm, which he had once taken for granted, now felt like a sacred liturgy. The pre-dawn chill, the heft of the milk pail, the rasp of a rough brush on a cow’s flank—each sensation was a confirmation that he was real, solid, and rooted in a world that made sense. He mended the weak fence on the north pasture, the physical exertion a welcome penance, and the repetitive thud of the mallet driving posts into the damp earth was a more honest and satisfying applause than anything he had heard in Oslo. He and Astrid fell into a careful, quiet truce. The X-Factor was a ghost that haunted the edges of their conversation, a topic too heavy to be named. She no longer looked at him with pleading eyes, but with a new, watchful maturity, her phone now used for schoolwork and chatting with local friends rather than for charting a course to a life of glamour. The peace he had reclaimed felt fragile, like a thin pane of ice over the deep, dark water of the fjord, but for a few precious days, it held.

The first crack appeared not on the farm, but in the village. He had driven the old truck into the small cluster of buildings that served as their local hub to pick up a new filter for the milking machine. As he stepped out onto the rain-slicked pavement, he noticed it immediately: the subtle shift in the way people looked at him. Margit, who ran the small grocery and had known him since he was a boy, stopped stacking oranges and stared at him with an uncharacteristic, open-mouthed grin. Old Man Halvorsen, who usually only grunted in greeting, actually tipped his hat. A car full of teenagers slowed down, and a girl with pink hair leaned out the window and shouted, “Sing for us, Farmer Bjørn!” before they sped off, laughing. In the corner shop, tucked between newspapers detailing fishing quotas and national politics, was a garish tabloid. And on the front page, under a headline that screamed ‘THE VOICE OF NORWAY?’, was a grainy, pixelated photo of him on the stage, his face contorted in a mask of emotional intensity. He stared at the image, a portrait of a stranger, and felt a cold dread seep into his bones. The ghost was not gone; it had followed him home.

The invasion began two days later. He was in the high pasture, checking on the younger heifers, the wind a clean, sharp presence against his face, when he saw the glint of sun on metal far down his private lane. It was a silver station wagon, wholly unfamiliar, and it was moving with a slow, predatory confidence. He watched as it pulled to a stop near the house, and two people got out: a man with a notepad and a woman laden with camera bags. They looked around, their city clothes starkly out of place against the backdrop of pine and weathered wood, their movements tentative, as if they were exploring an alien planet. By the time he had descended the slope, his heart thumping a heavy, resentful rhythm, they were at his front door, peering through the windows. “This is private land,” he said, his voice a low growl. The man turned, his face breaking into a practiced, friendly smile. “Mr. Knutsen! A pleasure. I’m Anders Fjell from the *Dagbladet*. We just want a few words. The whole country is talking about you. Your story is an inspiration.” Bjørn stood before them, a wall of silent refusal, his arms crossed over his chest. “My story is that I am a farmer, and I am busy. And you are trespassing.” The woman lifted her camera, but before she could raise it to her eye, Astrid appeared from the barn. “He said to leave,” she said, her voice quiet but firm, devoid of its previous awe for the outside world. She stood beside her father, a small but resolute ally. The journalist, seeing no way past the united, granite-like defiance of the Knutsens, sighed and retreated to the car, but not before shouting, “The public has a right to know you, Bjørn!”

He thought, for a moment, that their stand had worked. But the article that appeared online that evening, complete with a long-lens photo of him glaring at them from his doorway, painted him as a recluse, a "hermit with a golden voice," making him even more of a mystique. For the next week, his life became a siege. Cars would park at the bottom of his lane, their occupants hoping for a glimpse of him. A drone, a buzzing mechanical insect, once appeared over the barn until he scared it off by brandishing a pitchfork. Lars took to screening his calls, gruffly telling reporters and television producers that Bjørn Knutsen was “unavailable for comment, now and forever.” The farm, his sanctuary, had become a fishbowl. The quiet he had fought to win back had been stolen, replaced by a constant, low-level hum of external scrutiny. He felt cornered, his temper fraying, his patience worn down to a nub. The peace was not just broken; it was shattered.

Then, on a Tuesday morning when a weak sun was doing its best to burn through the persistent mist, the black Mercedes returned. It navigated the muddy, rutted lane with an insultingly smooth assurance and crunched to a halt in the yard, its gleaming paintwork a flagrant violation of the farm’s muted, earthy palette. The driver’s door opened, and Sofia Dahl emerged. She was not wearing her sharp city suit. Instead, she was clad in brand-new, impeccably clean hiking boots, expensive-looking outdoor trousers, and a fashionable waterproof jacket. It was a costume, just as his suit had been, a calculated attempt to meet him on his own turf. She looked at the mud, the chickens scattering at her feet, and the imposing silence of the man who stood waiting for her by the barn door, and her smile did not falter. “Bjørn,” she said, her voice bright and clear. “I thought I’d come to you this time.”

She was a masterful tactician. She didn’t talk about the show, not at first. She asked for a tour. With a mixture of morbid curiosity and grim resignation, he walked her through the barn. She made all the right noises, complimenting the sturdy construction, asking about the cows by name, and even stroking Helga’s nose with a tentative, manicured hand, proclaiming her “magnificent.” She spoke of the beauty of the fjord and the “soul” of the place, her words like polished stones, smooth and without real texture. He remained silent, offering only grunts and nods, refusing to give her any purchase. Finally, standing in the centre of the barn, the scent of hay and honest work surrounding them, she stopped. “Your performance has been viewed over five million times, Bjørn. In less than two weeks. The network has never seen anything like it. You are not just a contestant anymore; you are a phenomenon.”

He stared at her, his face unreadable. “I am a farmer.” She met his gaze, her expression turning serious, persuasive. “You are. And that’s what people love. We don’t want to change that. We want to celebrate it. The offer for the next round is still open, but it’s different now. We will work around you. We’ll send a vocal coach here. We’ll film segments of you working, living your life. You won’t have to be in Oslo for more than a day or two at a time. The final contract… Bjørn, the money we are prepared to offer could buy this valley. It could send Astrid to any university in the world. It could ensure that a Knutsen is still on this land a hundred and fifty years from now.” She took a step closer, her voice dropping to an intimate, conspiratorial whisper. “You think you are protecting your peace by hiding. But they won’t stop. The reporters, the tourists… they will keep coming, trying to steal a piece of you. With us, you control the narrative. You tell your story, your way. You can’t put the song back in your throat, Bjørn. So why not get paid for it?” He stood motionless, the dust motes dancing in the sunbeams around her, the gentle chewing of the cows the only sound. He looked past her, through the wide-open barn doors, towards the old house. In the kitchen window, he could see the faint silhouette of his daughter, watching them. Sofia had laid out the choice with brutal clarity. It was no longer a question of his peace versus a fleeting moment of fame. It was a choice between a life of quiet dignity under constant siege, or a life of managed celebrity that could secure his daughter’s future and, just maybe, protect the very farm he was trying to hide. He felt the fjord stone in his pocket, a cold, hard reminder of a simple choice that was no longer simple at all.The silence that followed Sofia’s proposal was not empty. It was filled with the soft rustle of hay as a cow shifted its weight, the distant cry of a gull over the fjord, and the frantic, silent turning of gears in Bjørn Knutsen’s soul. He looked at this woman in her absurdly clean outdoor gear, a missionary of Mammon standing on his hallowed ground, and he felt a weary, profound anger. She had dissected his life, identified his weakest points—his love for his daughter, his fealty to his land—and was now applying pressure with surgical precision. She was not offering him a gift; she was showing him the fine print on a devil’s bargain. He turned his head and looked past her, his gaze landing on the silhouette of his daughter in the kitchen window. Astrid was the future. The land was the past. And he was the precarious, stubborn bridge standing between them.

“You have said what you came to say,” he said, his voice flat and devoid of emotion. He turned his back on her and walked towards Helga’s stall, picking up a pitchfork as he went. The familiar weight of the tool in his hands was a small comfort, an anchor to a world of tangible tasks and honest labour. “The road you came on is the same road you will take to leave. I have chores to do.” It was a dismissal as absolute as a slammed door. Sofia Dahl, for the first time, looked momentarily wrong-footed. She had expected an argument, a negotiation, a surrender. She had not expected to be ignored, to be rendered as irrelevant as a fly in a barn. Yet, she recovered instantly, her professional smile clicking back into place. “I’ll be at my hotel in Oslo until tomorrow evening, Bjørn. The offer stands. Think about what your life will look like a month from now, with or without us.” With that, she turned and walked out of the barn, her new boots crunching on the gravel, a sound of retreat that felt, unnervingly, like a victory.

Bjørn did not watch her go. He forked fresh hay into Helga’s manger with a furious, mechanical efficiency, his movements jerky and too forceful. The cow watched him with her placid, deep eyes, sensing the turmoil that roiled beneath his placid surface. He had won the small battle, sent the invader packing, but he knew he was losing the war. Sofia’s words echoed in the quiet of the barn, a poison seeping into the soil of his certainty. *You can’t put the song back in your throat.* He had become public property. His peace was no longer his to command. He could barricade the doors and curse the trespassers, but they would always be there, just beyond the fence line, their cameras like vultures waiting for a sign of life. He finished his work, the familiar tasks failing to provide their usual solace, and walked slowly towards the house, feeling the weight of the last hundred and fifty years of Knutsen men on his broad shoulders.

Astrid was sitting at the big wooden kitchen table, a half-finished glass of milk in front of her, her homework forgotten. She looked up as he entered, her young face etched with a worry that made her look years older. He pulled out a chair and sat down heavily, the old wood groaning in protest. For a long time, neither of them spoke. They just listened to the familiar sounds of the house: the hum of the old refrigerator, the ticking of the grandfather clock in the hall, a sound that had measured out the lives and deaths of his entire family line. It was Bjørn who finally broke the silence, his voice rough. “She offered a great deal of money.” He did not look at his daughter, but at his own hands resting on the table, the skin thick and mapped with a lifetime of work. “She said it could secure this place. For you. For the future.”

“I heard,” Astrid said quietly. “I saw her talking. I don’t care about the money, Papa.” He finally raised his eyes to meet hers. He saw the truth of her words, but he also saw the lie. She was sixteen. Of course she cared. She was a bright girl trapped in a quiet valley, and the world Sofia had dangled before them was a world of infinite possibility. “Don’t lie to me, Astrid. Not about this,” he said, his voice softening. “It is a father’s job to want more for his child than he had himself. My world is this house, that barn, and the land up to the ridge. Is that the only world you want?” Tears welled in her eyes, tears of frustration and love and confusion. “I want you to be happy!” she whispered fiercely. “When you were on that stage… for a minute, you looked… I don’t know. Not happy. But alive. More alive than you’ve been since Mama died. But then, when you came home, that light was gone. All I want is for you to get that light back. If singing for those people does it, then do it. If it doesn’t, then tell them all to go to hell. But don’t do it for me. Or for the money.”

Her words, so full of a simple, youthful wisdom, cut him to the core. She hadn’t seen the future security or the university education; she had seen a flicker of light in her grieving father and had mistaken it for joy. He had not been more alive on that stage; he had simply been a nerve, exposed and screaming. He reached across the table and covered her small hand with his large one. “The light, as you call it, comes from the singing, my girl. It does not come from the audience.” He sighed, a sound like the wind leaking through an old window frame. “But that woman was right about one thing. They will not leave us alone. They will chip away at this place, at our quiet, until there is nothing left but a story in a newspaper and a bitter old man.” He stood up and went to the window, looking out at the fjord, its surface a sheet of dark, hammered silver under the afternoon sky. He had always seen the farm as a fortress. Now he saw it as a ship, adrift and taking on water. And he was its captain.

That evening, he did something he hadn’t done in years. After the chores were done and Astrid had retreated to her room, he climbed the steep path behind the house, up to the high ridge that overlooked the entire valley. It was a place he had gone with his father as a boy, and later with Ingrid on long summer evenings. He sat on a flat, moss-covered stone that still held a faint warmth from the day’s weak sun and looked down. He saw his world laid out before him: the sturdy house with its single light burning in the kitchen, the dark, solid shape of the barn, the fields stitched together by stone walls, and beyond, the fjord, a vast and silent presence connecting him to the wider world he so desperately wished to ignore. He thought of his grandfather, who had built this farm with his bare hands, a man who had faced blizzards and famine and had refused to break. He thought of his father, who had modernized the farm, bringing in electricity and machinery, fighting a different kind of battle against obsolescence. Each generation had faced its own dragon. Perhaps this was his. A dragon made of cameras and contracts and the insatiable hunger of a public that wanted to own a piece of his soul. To hide was to let the dragon circle, to let it lay waste to his peace at its leisure. To fight… to fight meant engaging it on its own terms.

He stayed there until the last of the light bled from the sky and the first stars pricked the deep velvet of the night. He thought of Astrid’s words, of his wife’s gentle encouragement, of Helga’s steadfast loyalty. And he thought of the song. The old stev he had sung on the stage. It was a lament for a man leaving his home, but it was also a promise to the mountains that he would return. Perhaps that was the answer. He could leave, but on his own terms. He could journey into that foreign world of noise and light, but he would not let it change him. He would be the Knutsen on the stage, the stubborn old man refusing to budge, singing his songs not for them, but for himself, for his past, for the land that held his heart. He would take their money, their devil’s bargain, and he would use it to reinforce the walls of his fortress, to ensure that the land would endure long after the last camera had been turned off. He stood up, the decision settling not with a sense of victory, but with the grim resolve of a soldier accepting his duty. He would not surrender. He would negotiate the terms of the war.

He walked back down to the house, the path familiar even in the deep dark. He entered the warm kitchen where Astrid had left a single lamp burning for him. He picked up the receiver of the landline, the plastic cool and solid in his hand. He found the business card Sofia had left on the table and, with a steady finger, dialled the number. As the phone began to ring, a distant, electronic sound connecting his world to hers, Astrid appeared in the doorway of the kitchen, her eyes wide with a question she was too afraid to ask. He looked at her and gave a slow, deliberate nod. On the third ring, Sofia answered, her voice crisp and professional. “Sofia Dahl.”

“This is Bjørn Knutsen,” he said, his voice a low rumble that seemed to rise from the very floorboards of the house. “I will sing for your show.” He heard her sharp intake of breath, the sound of a predator sensing victory. But before she could speak, he cut her off, his tone leaving no room for argument. “But there are conditions. My conditions. You will listen to them now, and you will not interrupt.” He paused, holding the silence, establishing the new dynamic. “First, I will not wear a suit.”There was a long pause on the other end of the line, a stretch of silence filled only by the faint, oceanic hiss of the connection. Bjørn could picture her, the producer, her mind racing, weighing variables, calculating angles. He did not rush to fill the void. He leaned into the microphone, his lips almost brushing the cool metal, and in the sudden, expectant hush, he spoke. His voice was not a whisper, not a growl, but a simple, clear statement of fact. “I have no song for you tonight.”

The final, piercing note of the kulning hung in the air for a long, vibrating moment and then, as if cut by a knife, it was gone. One rain-lashed Tuesday afternoon, Bjørn came into the warm, bright kitchen after a long morning spent clearing a winter-felled pine from the fence line. Astrid looked up, a flicker of defensiveness in her eyes that quickly softened when she saw he was not angry, only watching her with a deep, searching tenderness. “They have one of the best marine biology programmes in the world,” she said, her voice a little shy, as if admitting to a secret ambition. “And… it looks like our mountains. A week later, the post boat delivered an unusual letter. It was a thin, air-mail envelope, its paper soft and almost translucent, covered in a spider-web of unfamiliar stamps and postmarks. The letter inside was written on a single, thin sheet of paper in the same spidery, elegant hand. It was brief.

*Mr. Knutsen,*

*I am a shepherd. I am eighty-three years old. I have spent my life on this island, in the company of sheep, the wind, and the ghosts of my family. My grandson, a good boy but with too much city in his ears, showed me a video on his telephone machine. It was of you. Not the American songs, which were very fine, but the other one. The first one you sang, and the last one.*

*I do not know the language of your call. But my grandfather, and his before him, used a sound like it to call the flock down from the Cuillins when the mist came in. Bjørn read the letter once, then a second time. He stood motionless in his kitchen, the flimsy piece of paper held in his thick, callused hands. This was not fan mail. It was not a request. As the summer waned, and the first hints of gold began to touch the leaves of the birch trees on the high slopes, a new kind of quiet settled over the farm. It was the quiet of waiting. The letter from Scotland was followed by another, and then another.
